title: How to Make Gluten‐Free Onion Rings

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and prepare a baking sheet.
steps.description: Turn the oven on to 400 degrees F (200 C). Get out a baking sheet and tear off a sheet of parchment paper. Lay the parchment paper on the baking sheet and set it aside.

steps.headline: Combine the dry seasoning mixture.
steps.description:
Get out a medium mixing bowl and measure all of the dry ingredients into it. Use a whisk to combine the ingredients . Set the bowl aside. For dry seasonings, you'll need:
½ cup (64 g) arrowroot powder
2 teaspoons paprika
1 1/2 teaspoons salt
1 teaspoon onion powder
1 teaspoon garlic powder
1 1/2 teaspoons sugar (optional)

steps.headline: Whisk together the wet mixture.
steps.description: Set a shallow bowl or pie plate on your work surface. Crack 1 egg into the dish and add ½ cup (120 ml) of coconut milk from a can. Whisk the egg and coconut milk until the egg is incorporated. Set the wet mixture aside. Try to use regular coconut milk (not light, since it can be too watery). Avoid using creamed coconut which is very thick and sweet.

steps.headline: Slice the onion.
steps.description: Take 1 large sweet onion (like Vidalia or Walla Walla) and remove the peel. Take a sharp knife and carefully slice the onion into 3/4-inch (19-mm) thick slices. Separate the individual rings, so you have lots of rings in different sizes.

steps.headline: Dip the onion rings into the wet mix.
steps.description: Take one onion at a time and dip it in the wet mixture. Turn each ring over, so it's completely coated in the coconut milk/egg mixture. Hold the coated ring up, so the excess mixture drips back into the pan. It may be easier to dip and coat the onion rings in small batches.

steps.headline: Dredge the coated onion rings in the dry mixture.
steps.description: Transfer the onion rings that are coated in the wet mixture into the bowl with the dry seasoning mixture. Turn each ring over, so they're coated with the dry mix. Hold up each ring and tap any of the excess dry mixture back into the mixing bowl. Removing excess dry mixture from each onion ring will help them crisp up. Too much coating will make the onion rings too soggy.

steps.headline: Spray the onion rings.
steps.description: Set each prepared onion ring on the baking sheet and spray all of them lightly with cooking spray. Turn them over and spray the other side. The cooking spray will help the onion rings brown and will prevent them from sticking to the baking sheet.

steps.headline: Bake the onion rings for a total of 14 minutes.
steps.description: Put the baking sheet in the oven and bake the onion rings for 10 minutes. Turn the rings over and bake them for another 4 minutes. The onion rings should become completely crispy and golden brown once they've finished baking. Serve the onion rings with your favorite dipping sauces. Avoid storing the leftovers.

steps.headline: Heat the canola oil in a large pot.
steps.description: Set a 4-quart Dutch oven or pot on the stove. Pour in 4 cups (946 ml) of canola oil and heat it over medium-high heat. Attach a candy or deep-fry thermometer onto the side of the pot, so you can adjust the temperature. You'll need to heat the oil to 385 degrees F (195 C) before you can begin frying the onion rings.

steps.headline: Whisk together the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Measure 1 cup (120 g) of gluten-free all-purpose flour, 1 cup (141 g) of white rice flour, 1 tablespoon of chili powder, and 1 teaspoon of baking soda into a mixing bowl. Whisk the ingredients together, so the spices are incorporated.

steps.headline: Whisk in the club soda.
steps.description: Keep whisking the dry ingredients and slowly pour in 1 1/4 cups (295 ml) of chilled club soda. The batter will foam up a little, but it should become smooth. Set it aside while you prepare the onion.

steps.headline: Slice the onion into rings.
steps.description: Peel 1 medium onion and remove the ends. Use a sharp knife to carefully slice the onion into 1/2-inch (12-mm) thick slices. Pull out each ring, so you have a variety of onion ring sizes.

steps.headline: Dip the onion rings into the batter.
steps.description: Dip each onion ring into the wet batter, so it's completely coated. Lift each ring up out of the batter and let the excess batter drip off before you fry the rings. This will help them crisp up more.

steps.headline: Fry the gluten-free onion rings.
steps.description: Check the oil temperature to ensure that it's at degrees F (195 C) . Add a few of the coated rings to the oil and fry them for 1 minute or until they're totally golden brown. The temperature of the oil will drop a little, but ensure that it stays around 375 F (190 C) while the rings are frying. Scoop out the fried onion rings and set them on a baking sheet lined with paper towels. Fry the rest of the onion rings in batches. Remember to let the oil heat back up to 385 degrees F (195 C) before you fry another batch of rings. Consider keeping the fried onion rings in a warm oven while you fry the rest of them.

steps.headline: Season the onion rings and serve them.
steps.description: In a small prep bowl, stir together 1/4 teaspoon of salt, 1/4 teaspoon of garlic powder, and 1/4 teaspoon of black pepper. Sprinkle the fried onion rings with the spice mixture and serve them immediately. Consider serving the rings with ketchup or your favorite condiments.

Making Deep-Fried Onion Rings (Gluten Free) Heat the canola oil in a large pot. Set a 4-quart Dutch oven or pot on the stove. Pour in 4 cups (946 ml) of canola oil and heat it over medium-high heat. Fry the gluten-free onion rings. Check the oil temperature to ensure that it's at degrees F (195 C) .
